title: Erdős #608: Edges in 5-Cycles
description: Does G with > n²/4 edges have ≥ (2/9)n² edges in C₅? NO! The correct bound is c = (2 + √2)/16 ≈ 0.2134. Füredi-Maleki and Grzesik-Hu-Volec determined the exact value.

meta.author: Paul Erdős, Zoltán Füredi, Dániel Maleki, Andrzej Grzesik, Ping Hu, Jan Volec

overview.historicalContext: Erdős asked whether graphs with > n²/4 edges must have (2/9)n² edges in 5-cycles. Füredi-Maleki constructed counterexamples showing the bound is unachievable. Grzesik-Hu-Volec proved the tight lower bound, determining c = (2 + √2)/16 ≈ 0.2134 is exact.
overview.problemStatement: Let G be a graph with n vertices and > n²/4 edges. Are there at least (2/9)n² edges of G contained in a C₅?
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize the C₅ definition, edge counting, the (false) original conjecture, the correct constant c = (2 + √2)/16, Füredi-Maleki upper bound, Grzesik-Hu-Volec lower bound, odd cycles in general, triangles, Turán threshold, and construction details.
keyInsights: Füredi-Maleki: Upper bound construction with cn² + O(n)
For C_{2k+1} with k ≥ 3, the bound (2/9)n² IS correct

sections.title: Füredi-Maleki Upper Bound
sections.summary: Construction with few edges in C₅

sections.title: Turán Threshold
sections.summary: At n²/4 edges, bipartite graphs have 0 edges in C₅

conclusion.summary: This formalization captures Erdős Problem #608 on edges in 5-cycles. The original conjecture of (2/9)n² edges is FALSE; the correct bound is c = (2 + √2)/16 ≈ 0.2134, determined exactly by Füredi-Maleki (upper) and Grzesik-Hu-Volec (lower).
conclusion.implications: The problem reveals that 5-cycles behave differently from longer odd cycles. For C_{2k+1} with k ≥ 3, the bound (2/9)n² IS correct. The special behavior of C₅ connects to algebraic constructions and blow-up techniques.
openQuestions: What is the exact structure of near-extremal graphs?
Is there a simpler proof of the lower bound?
